trans-unit.source: How to Use CoreOS | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to Use CoreOS | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes CoreOS, how to create a CoreOS virtual machine cluster on Azure, and its basic usage.
trans-unit.target: Describes CoreOS, how to create a CoreOS virtual machine cluster on Azure, and its basic usage.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes [CoreOS] and shows how to create a cluster of three CoreOS virtual machines on Azure as a quick start to understanding this operating system.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes [CoreOS] and shows how to create a cluster of three CoreOS virtual machines on Azure as a quick start to understanding this operating system.

trans-unit.source: It uses the very basic elements of CoreOS deployments and examples from [CoreOS with Azure], [Tim Park's CoreOS Tutorial], and [Patrick Chanezon's CoreOS Tutorial] to demonstrate the absolute minimum requirements to both understand the basic structure of a CoreOS deployment and get a cluster of three virtual machines running successfully.
trans-unit.target: It uses the very basic elements of CoreOS deployments and examples from [CoreOS with Azure], [Tim Park's CoreOS Tutorial], and [Patrick Chanezon's CoreOS Tutorial] to demonstrate the absolute minimum requirements to both understand the basic structure of a CoreOS deployment and get a cluster of three virtual machines running successfully.

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to use the Azure command-line interface with Service Management commands to create the CoreOS VMs.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to use the Azure command-line interface with Service Management commands to create the CoreOS VMs.

trans-unit.source: To get started with CoreOS in Azure Resource Manager, try this <linkText>quickstart template</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To get started with CoreOS in Azure Resource Manager, try this <linkText>quickstart template</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: CoreOS is a lightweight version of Linux designed to support rapid creation of potentially very large clusters of VMs that use Linux containers as the only packaging mechanism, including [Docker] containers.
trans-unit.target: CoreOS is a lightweight version of Linux designed to support rapid creation of potentially very large clusters of VMs that use Linux containers as the only packaging mechanism, including [Docker] containers.

trans-unit.source: CoreOS is intended to support:
trans-unit.target: CoreOS is intended to support:

trans-unit.source: a very high level of automation
trans-unit.target: a very high level of automation

trans-unit.source: easier and more consistent application deployment
trans-unit.target: easier and more consistent application deployment

trans-unit.source: scalability at the application level and system level
trans-unit.target: scalability at the application level and system level

trans-unit.source: At a high level, the CoreOS features that support these goals are:
trans-unit.target: At a high level, the CoreOS features that support these goals are:

trans-unit.source: One package system: CoreOS runs only Linux container images that run in Linux containers for speed, uniformity, and ease of deployment
trans-unit.target: One package system: CoreOS runs only Linux container images that run in Linux containers for speed, uniformity, and ease of deployment

trans-unit.source: Operating system updates that are performed atomically so that operating systems are updated as a single entity and can be easily rolled back to a known state
trans-unit.target: Operating system updates that are performed atomically so that operating systems are updated as a single entity and can be easily rolled back to a known state

trans-unit.source: Built-in <linkText>etcd</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>fleet</linkText><title></title> daemons (services) for dynamic VM and cluster communication and management
trans-unit.target: Built-in <linkText>etcd</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>fleet</linkText><title></title> daemons (services) for dynamic VM and cluster communication and management

trans-unit.source: This is a very general description of CoreOS and its features.
trans-unit.target: This is a very general description of CoreOS and its features.

trans-unit.source: For more complete information about CoreOS, see the [CoreOS Overview].
trans-unit.target: For more complete information about CoreOS, see the [CoreOS Overview].

trans-unit.source: Currently, CoreOS assumes that those who can SSH into the cluster have permission to manage it.
trans-unit.target: Currently, CoreOS assumes that those who can SSH into the cluster have permission to manage it.

trans-unit.source: The result is that without modification, CoreOS clusters are outstanding for test and development environments, but you should apply further security measures in any production environment.
trans-unit.target: The result is that without modification, CoreOS clusters are outstanding for test and development environments, but you should apply further security measures in any production environment.

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to create an Azure cloud cervice with three CoreOS virtual machines in it using the [Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)].
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to create an Azure cloud cervice with three CoreOS virtual machines in it using the [Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)].

trans-unit.source: The basic steps are as follows:
trans-unit.target: The basic steps are as follows:

trans-unit.source: Create the SSH certificates and keys to secure communication with the CoreOS virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Create the SSH certificates and keys to secure communication with the CoreOS virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Obtain your cluster's etcd id for intercommunication
trans-unit.target: Obtain your cluster's etcd id for intercommunication

trans-unit.source: Create a cloud-config file in [YAML] format
trans-unit.target: Create a cloud-config file in [YAML] format

trans-unit.source: Use the Azure CLI to create a new Azure cloud service and three CoreOS VMs
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure CLI to create a new Azure cloud service and three CoreOS VMs

trans-unit.source: Test your CoreOS cluster from an Azure VM
trans-unit.target: Test your CoreOS cluster from an Azure VM

trans-unit.source: Test your CoreOS cluster from localhost
trans-unit.target: Test your CoreOS cluster from localhost

trans-unit.source: Use the instructions in <linkText>How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure</linkText><title></title> to create a public and private key for SSH.
trans-unit.target: Use the instructions in <linkText>How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure</linkText><title></title> to create a public and private key for SSH.

trans-unit.source: (The basic steps are in the instructions below.)
trans-unit.target: (The basic steps are in the instructions below.)

trans-unit.source: You are going to use these keys to connect to VMs in the cluster to verify that they are working and can communicate with each other.
trans-unit.target: You are going to use these keys to connect to VMs in the cluster to verify that they are working and can communicate with each other.

trans-unit.source: This topic assumes that you do not have these keys, and requires you to create myPrivateKey.pem and myCert.pem files for clarity.
trans-unit.target: This topic assumes that you do not have these keys, and requires you to create myPrivateKey.pem and myCert.pem files for clarity.

trans-unit.source: If you already have a public and private key pair saved to ~/.ssh/id_rsa, you can just type openssl req -x509 -key ~/.ssh/id_rsa -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -out myCert.pem to obtain the .pem file that you need to upload to Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you already have a public and private key pair saved to ~/.ssh/id_rsa, you can just type openssl req -x509 -key ~/.ssh/id_rsa -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -out myCert.pem to obtain the .pem file that you need to upload to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In a working directory, type openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout myPrivateKey.key -out myCert.pem to create the private key and an the X.509 certificate associated with it.
trans-unit.target: In a working directory, type openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout myPrivateKey.key -out myCert.pem to create the private key and an the X.509 certificate associated with it.

trans-unit.source: To assert that the private key's owner can read or write the file, type chmod 600 myPrivateKey.key.
trans-unit.target: To assert that the private key's owner can read or write the file, type chmod 600 myPrivateKey.key.

trans-unit.source: You should now have both a myPrivateKey.key and a myCert.pem file in your working directory.
trans-unit.target: You should now have both a myPrivateKey.key and a myCert.pem file in your working directory.

trans-unit.source: CoreOS's etcd daemon requires a discovery id to query for all nodes in the cluster automatically.
trans-unit.target: CoreOS's etcd daemon requires a discovery id to query for all nodes in the cluster automatically.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve your discovery id and save it to an etcdid file, type
trans-unit.target: To retrieve your discovery id and save it to an etcdid file, type

trans-unit.source: Still in the same working directory, create a file with your favorite text editor with the following text and save it as cloud-config.yaml.
trans-unit.target: Still in the same working directory, create a file with your favorite text editor with the following text and save it as cloud-config.yaml.

trans-unit.source: (You can save it as any file name you want, but when you create your VMs in the next step, you'll need to reference this file's name in your --custom-data option for the azure vm create command.)
trans-unit.target: (You can save it as any file name you want, but when you create your VMs in the next step, you'll need to reference this file's name in your --custom-data option for the azure vm create command.)

trans-unit.source: Remember to type cat etcdid to retrieve the etcd discovery id from the etcdid file you created above and replace in the following cloud-config.yaml file with the generated number from your etcdid file. If you are unable to validate your cluster at the end, this may be one of the steps you overlooked!
trans-unit.target: Remember to type cat etcdid to retrieve the etcd discovery id from the etcdid file you created above and replace in the following cloud-config.yaml file with the generated number from your etcdid file. If you are unable to validate your cluster at the end, this may be one of the steps you overlooked!

trans-unit.source: (For more complete information about the cloud-config file, see <linkText>Using Cloud-Config</linkText><title></title> in the CoreOS documentation.)
trans-unit.target: (For more complete information about the cloud-config file, see <linkText>Using Cloud-Config</linkText><title></title> in the CoreOS documentation.)

trans-unit.source: Install the [Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)] if you have not already done so, and either login using a work or school ID, or download a .publishsettings file and import that into your account.
trans-unit.target: Install the [Azure Command-line Interface (Azure CLI)] if you have not already done so, and either login using a work or school ID, or download a .publishsettings file and import that into your account.

trans-unit.source: Locate your CoreOS image.
trans-unit.target: Locate your CoreOS image.

trans-unit.source: To locate the images available at any time, type azure vm image list | grep CoreOS and you should see a list of results similar to:
trans-unit.target: To locate the images available at any time, type azure vm image list | grep CoreOS and you should see a list of results similar to:

trans-unit.source: data: 2b171e93f07c4903bcad35bda10acf22__CoreOS-Stable-522.6.0 Public Linux
trans-unit.target: data: 2b171e93f07c4903bcad35bda10acf22__CoreOS-Stable-522.6.0 Public Linux

trans-unit.source: Create a cloud service for your basic cluster by typing azure service create where <cloud-service-name> is the name for your CoreOS cloud service. This sample uses the name **coreos-cluster**; you will need to reuse the name that you choose to create your CoreOS VM instances inside the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Create a cloud service for your basic cluster by typing azure service create where <cloud-service-name> is the name for your CoreOS cloud service. This sample uses the name **coreos-cluster**; you will need to reuse the name that you choose to create your CoreOS VM instances inside the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: One note: If you observe your work so far in the <linkText>preview portal</linkText><title></title>, you'll find your cloud service name is both a resource group and domain, as the following image shows:
trans-unit.target: One note: If you observe your work so far in the <linkText>preview portal</linkText><title></title>, you'll find your cloud service name is both a resource group and domain, as the following image shows:

trans-unit.source: Connect to your cloud service and create a new CoreOS VM inside by using the azure vm create command.
trans-unit.target: Connect to your cloud service and create a new CoreOS VM inside by using the azure vm create command.

trans-unit.source: You'll pass the location of your X.509 certificate in the --ssh-cert option.
trans-unit.target: You'll pass the location of your X.509 certificate in the --ssh-cert option.

trans-unit.source: Create your first VM image by typing the following, remembering to replace coreos-cluster with the cloud service name that you created:
trans-unit.target: Create your first VM image by typing the following, remembering to replace coreos-cluster with the cloud service name that you created:

trans-unit.source: Create the second node by repeating the command in step 4, replacing the --vm-name value with node-2 and the --ssh port value with 2022.
trans-unit.target: Create the second node by repeating the command in step 4, replacing the --vm-name value with node-2 and the --ssh port value with 2022.

trans-unit.source: Create the third node by repeating the command in step 4, replacing the --vm-name value with node-3 and the --ssh port value with 3022.
trans-unit.target: Create the third node by repeating the command in step 4, replacing the --vm-name value with node-3 and the --ssh port value with 3022.

trans-unit.source: You can see from the shot below how the CoreOS cluster appears in the portal.
trans-unit.target: You can see from the shot below how the CoreOS cluster appears in the portal.

trans-unit.source: To test your cluster, make sure you are in your working directory and then connect to node-1 using ssh, passing the private key by typing:
trans-unit.target: To test your cluster, make sure you are in your working directory and then connect to node-1 using ssh, passing the private key by typing:

trans-unit.source: Once connected, type sudo fleetctl list-machines to see whether the cluster has already identified all VMs in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Once connected, type sudo fleetctl list-machines to see whether the cluster has already identified all VMs in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: You should receive a response similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should receive a response similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Finally, let's test your CoreOS cluster from your local Linux client.
trans-unit.target: Finally, let's test your CoreOS cluster from your local Linux client.

trans-unit.source: You might be able to install fleetctl by using npm, or you might want to install fleet and build fleetctl yourself on your local client.
trans-unit.target: You might be able to install fleetctl by using npm, or you might want to install fleet and build fleetctl yourself on your local client.

trans-unit.source: fleet requires golang, so you may need to install that first by typing:
trans-unit.target: fleet requires golang, so you may need to install that first by typing:

trans-unit.source: sudo apt-get install golang
trans-unit.target: sudo apt-get install golang

trans-unit.source: Then clone the fleet repository from github by typing:
trans-unit.target: Then clone the fleet repository from github by typing:

trans-unit.source: git clone https://github.com/coreos/fleet.git
trans-unit.target: git clone https://github.com/coreos/fleet.git

trans-unit.source: Build fleet by changing to the fleet directory and type
trans-unit.target: Build fleet by changing to the fleet directory and type

trans-unit.source: ./build
trans-unit.target: ./build

trans-unit.source: And finally place fleet for easy use (depending upon your configuration you may or may not need to sudo):
trans-unit.target: And finally place fleet for easy use (depending upon your configuration you may or may not need to sudo):

trans-unit.source: cp bin/fleetctl /usr/local/bin
trans-unit.target: cp bin/fleetctl /usr/local/bin

trans-unit.source: Make sure fleet has access to your myPrivateKey.key in the working directory by typing:
trans-unit.target: Make sure fleet has access to your myPrivateKey.key in the working directory by typing:

trans-unit.source: ssh-add ./myPrivateKey.key
trans-unit.target: ssh-add ./myPrivateKey.key

trans-unit.source: If you are already using the ~/.ssh/id_rsa key, then add that with ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa.
trans-unit.target: If you are already using the ~/.ssh/id_rsa key, then add that with ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa.

trans-unit.source: Now you are ready to test remotely using the same fleetctl command you used from node-1, but passing some remote arguments:
trans-unit.target: Now you are ready to test remotely using the same fleetctl command you used from node-1, but passing some remote arguments:

trans-unit.source: fleetctl --tunnel coreos-cluster.cloudapp.net:22 list-machines
trans-unit.target: fleetctl --tunnel coreos-cluster.cloudapp.net:22 list-machines

trans-unit.source: The results should be exactly the same:
trans-unit.target: The results should be exactly the same:

trans-unit.source: You should now have a running three-node CoreOS cluster on Azure.
trans-unit.target: You should now have a running three-node CoreOS cluster on Azure.

trans-unit.source: From here, you can explore how to create more complex clusters and use Docker and create more interesting applications.
trans-unit.target: From here, you can explore how to create more complex clusters and use Docker and create more interesting applications.

trans-unit.source: To try a couple of quick examples, see [Get Started with Fleet on CoreOS on Azure].
trans-unit.target: To try a couple of quick examples, see [Get Started with Fleet on CoreOS on Azure].
